Sahil Bloom How to win‚Ä¶

(without talent or luck):

We all want to win.

Our definitions of ‚Äúwinning‚Äù vary‚Äîit may mean happiness and fulfillment to some, money and fame to others‚Äîbut in some way, shape, or form, we all want to win.

Here‚Äôs how:

1. Operate in Your Zone of Genius

Your Zone of Genius is where your interests, passions and skills align.

Operating in your Zone of Genius means playing games you are uniquely well-suited to win. 

Once you identify it, you can stop playing *their* games and start playing *yours*.

2. Adopt a Positive Sum Mentality

Want to get ahead in life? Start genuinely rooting for others to succeed.

When one of us wins, we all win‚Äîwinning spreads. If you adopt that mentality, you‚Äôll become a magnet for the highest quality people.

3. Speak Up

Closed mouths don‚Äôt get fed. A little push goes a long way.

Don't sit back and wait for good things to happen. If you want something‚Äîand you‚Äôve put in the work for it‚Äîspeak up and ask for it.

Worst Case: you‚Äôre told no and nothing has changed.

Best Case: it‚Äôs yours.

4. Play Long-Term Games

Life is the ultimate long game.

Those with low time preference play it more effectively‚Äîthey happily delay gratification to allow compounding to work its magic.

In a world of people seeking instant gratification, this is a meaningful edge.

5. Have a High Tolerance for Failure

We fear failure, so most of us play it safe to avoid it. But our greatest moments of growth often stem directly from our greatest failures.

Don't accept failure, but don't fear it either.

You will fail. Embrace it. Fail smart and fast.

6. Follow Your Curiosity

Humans are born with astonishing curiosity. But somewhere along the way, we're told to stop asking questions.

Push back.

Learn to follow your curiosity‚Äîtrust it. For the curious mind, anything is possible. Fortune favors the curious.

7. Adopt a Process Orientation

Prioritize process, not outcomes.
When you prioritize process, you become flexible in where you are headed‚Äîyou focus on the inputs and stop worrying about the outputs.

Just keep laying one brick at a time‚Äîforward progress is all that matters.

8. Prioritize People

Everything in life comes down to people and relationships.

Networks compound as well as any financial investment. Build an army of mentors, friends, and evangelists that is deep and wide. Cultivate deep relationships, but also embrace the power of weak ties.

9. Work Like a Lion

Modern work culture is a remnant of the Industrial Age. It encourages long periods of steady, monotonous work unsuited for the Information Age.

If your goal is to do inspired, creative work, you have to work as a lion works.

Sprint when inspired. Rest. Repeat.

One story gave me the courage to do it:

There's an old fable about Christopher Columbus that goes something like this‚Ä¶

In 1493, after his first voyage to the Americas, Columbus attended a dinner with Spanish nobles who dismissed his accomplishment:

"Anyone could have sailed west and found land."

Columbus smiled, reached for a boiled egg, and proposed a simple wager:

"Stand this egg on its tip, and I'll concede your point."

One by one, the nobles tried. One by one, they failed. Frustration filled the room.

Columbus then took the same egg, gave the tip a gentle tap that flattened a sliver of shell, and set it upright.

"Once you see the move, it feels inevitable," he said.

Here's the lesson that changed my life:

Obvious is a post-achievement label.

Breakthroughs are obvious only in hindsight.

That view erases the struggle, the ridicule, and the failure absorbed by the pioneer along the way.

Recent history proves this pattern:

‚Ä¢ A prominent venture capitalist called Airbnb a ‚Äúserial killer app‚Äù for its 
idea of strangers sleeping on your couch
‚Ä¢Incumbents ridiculed Apple for removing the keyboard when it launched the iPhone
‚Ä¢Blockbuster execs shrugged off Netflix when approached about an acquisition

The best ideas look crazy‚Äîuntil someone does them.

What‚Äôs the idea sitting in your Notes app that feels obvious to you but crazy to everyone else?

True innovation is met with ridicule at the outset. Enduring it is the cost of entry for anyone who wants to alter the status quo.

Innovation is about everyone agreeing with you...later.

The mindset shift that changed everything:

Focus on your trend-line, not your position.

We‚Äôve all felt it‚Äîthat knot in your chest when a friend announces the promotion, the bonus, the new house. A daily highlight reel reminds you exactly where they are‚Äì‚Äìand where you aren‚Äôt.

Teddy Roosevelt called comparison ‚Äúthe thief of joy,‚Äù but the real villain isn‚Äôt comparison itself‚Äîit‚Äôs the snapshot focus on where you stand right now.

Shift the lens to your trend. If you plotted your life like a chart, would you rather be the person at a high point drifting sideways‚Äîor the one starting lower but compounding upward every day?

Trend-thinking is pro-agentic. It says, I can‚Äôt alter today‚Äôs coordinates, but I can tilt the slope of tomorrow. That slope is forged in the mundane‚Äîcontrollable habits, routines, mindsets.

Three quick checks to reset your focus:

 1. If I copied today 100 times, would my trend rise or fall?

 2. Which single habit, done daily for 30 days, would bend my curve most?

 3. What subtle evidence of growth did I miss last month?

Stop self-inflicting misery with snapshot envy. Return to your craft. Stack tiny wins until the graph can‚Äôt hide them.

The carpenter reluctantly agreed, figuring he could get it done quickly. He cut corners, used cheap materials, and rushed through the work.

When the house was done, his boss arrived for the final inspection. But instead of walking the house, he reached into his pocket, and handed the carpenter the keys.

‚ÄúThis is your house,‚Äù his boss smiled, ‚ÄúMy retirement gift to you.‚Äù

The carpenter was stunned. If he‚Äôd known he was building his own house, he would have done it differently. Now he‚Äôd have to live in a house he had built none too well.

Cut corners, rush, and you‚Äôll live with it.
